title: F40 Vs. F40.
snippet: Hey Guys, does anyone know why the Euro cars received adjustable suspension while the US was stuck with the standard coil overs? How about the...
author: F40

posts.author: F40
posts.content: Hey Guys, does anyone know why the Euro cars received adjustable suspension while the US was stuck with the standard coil overs? How about the Euro cars getting harnesses while the US cars got the auto sliding 3 point annoying things that strangle you and break repeatedly? Is there any truth to US cars having more power then the Euro cars due to how they tuned the cars to meet emissions here. Finally, will my 6'3"-6'4" frame fit in the worlds greatest car, and my favorite car? Thanks.

posts.author: WILLIAM H
posts.content: Its going to be Very tight.  I am 5'10" & I barely have enough leg room with the seat all the way back You could just take the seat out & put pads on the floor like they do in race cars

posts.author: N24RE
posts.content: Here are a few more answers: 1) The Euro car got it due to the fact we americans always get a bit less than the best from Europe/Japan. Also the car is perfect with the standard suspension anyway. Lamborghini has the adjustable and it is just a pain in the butt! 2) Harnesses...simple...Department Of Transportation will not allow them.Also during the time of the F40,348 and TR the DOT was requiring "Passive Safety Devices"...thus the mouse belt was born...and was later replaced with Air Bags....a major improvement. 3) The US car is a bit lower in power due to the cats, but all of this is relative since the boost knob can be turned up or down depending on your taste. Now keep in mind not all Euro cars are the same. A Swiss car is the lowest power due to their strict sound requirements. 4) As William stated...it will be tight. Also it depends on where your height is. If you are all legs it will be a problem, but if you are a mix of leg and upper body then you will fit...but it will be tight. There is room to modify the seat tracks a bit to get more room. I Williams car I think he is giving up a touch of room due to the additon of the 6 point harnesses. the mounting brakets for the harnesses raise the seats by about 0.5" I am 6.0' and weigh 250 bodybuilder type pounds ( ie no beer gut )...I fit....like a glove in my opinion Ciao' Steve www.f1design.us _____ Hey Guys, does anyone know why the Euro cars received adjustable suspension while the US was stuck with the standard coil overs? How about the Euro cars getting harnesses while the US cars got the auto sliding 3 point annoying things that strangle you and break repeatedly? Is there any truth to US cars having more power then the Euro cars due to how they tuned the cars to meet emissions here. Finally, will my 6'3"-6'4" frame fit in the worlds greatest car, and my favorite car? Thanks.

posts.author: VROOM!!!
posts.content: Finally, a reason to hate Switzerland!loll..j/k.

posts.author: Roland E Linder
posts.content: I don't know about HP for stock F40, but I'm 6'3 185lbs and after chassis change and with the Momo seat "I'm comfit...I turned the supports rails upside down to lower the seat to give more head room with a helmet.. Nothing that a torche can't change !!! Roland F40LM

posts.author: F40
posts.content: I have really long legs and a long neck, I'm like a dinosaur. I fit in the TR like a glove, I fit in a 348TS with the CF seats and 5 point belts, but only with the roof off, and my head was still sticking above the windscreen a bit. Here are pics of me next to f-cars... I'm as tall as the 355 when crouching down. Image Unavailable, Please Login Image Unavailable, Please Login

posts.author: N24RE
posts.content: welll....best thing to do is go try one on for size! Ciao' =-) Steve

posts.author: rexrcr
posts.content: The adjustable suspension can be installed into any US F40.  That said, IMHO it's not worth it.  It only adjusts ride height, and is speed sensitive.  So it's just for negotiating bumpy city streets, and lowering for higher speed roadways. One of our members here has it installed, perhaps he'll offer up his experiences. Adding a six point harness is easy (except for upholstery) to a USA car, and adds NO height to the seat. At 6'-3" you'll be tight, but you must sit and drive to find out. Yes, the US cars do have a bit more power, not less, than Euro spec cars due to the exhausts hot catalysts.  This is confirmed by a factory source known to me when the cars were new in 1992-3.  He stated most USA engines dyno'd closer to 500 bhp, as opposed to 478 bhp. Best regards, Rob Schermerhorn

title: F40
snippet:
Question, what mods are easy safe and reliable for the F40.
I am thinking of Brakes and a little engine work?
author: king1sg

posts.author: king1sg
posts.content: Question, what mods are easy safe and reliable for the F40. I am thinking of Brakes and a little engine work?

posts.author: amenasce
posts.content: bigger brakes require bigger wheels . Tubi LM should also be an easy mod.

posts.author: zsnnf
posts.content: New turbos with chips and a tubi exhaust really wake the car up. Bigger brakes with 18" wheels help with repeated hard stops. Contact Rod at FAI @  949 631-6373 for the turbo's and chips. Rick

posts.author: reflex
posts.content: The Tubi exhaust with some adjustment can give 15bhp compared to the standard exhaust. I had a recent coversation with a famous Ferrari race development company who have dynoed an F40 engine on an engine dyno, not a rolling road - they did tests back to back. So a Tubi will give good power gains with little initial outlay. Brakes - proper LM ducting to keep them cool and a new dual master cylinder.

title: F40
snippet: If buying an F40, is there any difference in the value between the different years?
author: Michael246

posts.author: Michael246
posts.content: If buying an F40, is there any difference in the value between the different years?

posts.author: Ingenere
posts.content: Generally the '92 cars can be a bit stronger.

posts.author: Michael246
posts.content: Any reason? Is there any difference in the cars?

posts.author: sherpa23
posts.content: Here we go again. Do a search and you will see the firestorm of this topic. You are asking two different questions: 1) are there differences and 2) are they priced differently. I'll start with this. From personal experience of what I have seen, build quality differs a lot from car to car. I have seen '90s and '91s that are way better than a lot of '92s. I have also seen some stellar '92s. Many people seem to think that the cars were just built better and better as time went on but I have seen two '92s where it looked like they just phoned it in. The panels were way off, the glue was weird, the welds were even worse than usual. You will find guys who will say the complete opposite. What this means is that you have to look at each car individually and go by each car's pluses and minuses. As far as differences, there were three different types of carbon kevlar weave made through out the run (at least on US cars) that I have seen. None of these are better than the others, just different. Beyond that, later cars have mechanical updates like a better placed clutch bleeder and some other stuff (compare differences in the oil caps, for instance). As far as value, people sometimes do ask more for '92s because it's a '92 but the actual price  an educated buyer pays is based on the condition of the car. F40 quality can vary so wildly and so many have serious deferred maintenance issues that you need to buy the best car you can, regardless of year or mileage. Low miles isn't always better with these. Hope that helps.

posts.content: Good summary.

title: F40
forum: Mid-Atlantic Region - USA (PA, DE, MD, DC, VA)
snippet: ...coming out passed all traffic after awhile, joking about seeing the F40 all day long. We're driving, we're chatting, F40!!!! Bro spots it at a...
author: CarreraGT

posts.author: CarreraGT
posts.content: ....Speechless. So my bro and I went for a cruise in Greeneville today to see what we could spot since the horse events are going on, traffic was terrible so we hit the backroads, coming out passed all traffic after awhile, joking about seeing the F40 all day long. We're driving, we're chatting, F40!!!! Bro spots it at a gas station so we pull in, as he is pulling out. We follow of course. On the offramp of 52 towards Wilmington, we're behind, I'm snapping pics, or trying to. I hear whisteling, bro downshifts floors it. F40 makes the best music I've ever heard, whistle gets rediculously loud, bye bye Ferrari. We're doing 110+ in my my brother's 911 trying to atleast keep track of him, no use in even trying to keep next to it or within a football field of it. Pull up at the light next to it, speechless. Words can't describe what I was seeing. The gentleman driving was incredibly nice as so was his wife. We chatted until the light changed and off he went in a roar. We followed for a few minutes and then let him go his way. I told him about ferrarichat and he said he will check it out. So I figured I'd make this thread for the story and "F40 guy" if you join, please introduce yourself! -Wes P.S. My adrenaline is still sky rocketing, the whole rest of the cruise I couldn't sit still or stop talking about it.

The whole trade plates V club plates thing. i  saw a F40 with trade plates at lygon street tonight. does this mean you can drive them? what are the rules? i heard this car belongs to the president of the ferrari club? also that you are not meant to drive with these plates after dusk? I think i learned that with club plates you could drive the car for a 20km radius around the registered address for "testing purposes"? so, theoretically, a carrera gt could be imported from the states and driven under the same arrangement? is this true? scott you can probably answers these qs!

From my understanding if something happens its goiing to hit the fan.  Dealer plates are used for the sole purpose of moving a non registered vehicle from one place to another or for demonstration etc. The best place to own one that is close by is NZ.

posts.author: AKA
posts.content: Well, meant to be. I heard they cracked down on dealer plates a little while back because it was being abused (Guy in my old Corvette club used to run a rare LHD model on trade plates, not that his business had ANYTHING to do with car sales, but this was before they got tight on it) People still run the risk, and I guess they can afford it if they get in trouble. But yeah, in an accident, I doubt there would be much covering them.

posts.author: PAP 348
posts.content: I looked into this here in Mount Isa actually. I talked to the guys at the local transport department about driving LHD cars on the road legally. They said any LHD car that is 30 yrs old can be registered in QLD and driven daily. As long as it has the appropriate stickers on it saying it is LHD etc...etc. Any LHD car under 30 yrs old can be registered through a car club under "club rego". This means the car can be driven on the road for "testing after modifications/re-fueling/testing after repairs/fitting new tyres/driving to and from car shows etc..etc. All have to be done within a 20 km radius of where the car is garaged. A letter from the Club President is proof that your LHD car is part of the Club which qualifies it for Club Rego. I have thought about this MANY times..........then come to the conclusion that I will be ****ed if I ever want to take a car that is not 30 yrs or older anywhere but 20 km from my house. We are lucky here in Mount Isa as its 10 km to the other side of town, so I reckon I could drive anywhere here without the worry of being out of my 20 km radius zone. What if I want to take the car for a drive out of town?? Im screwed then. Even if I trailered it to Townsville or Brisbane, I wouldnt be allowed to drive it as its out of the 20 km radius zone. So you have to be pretty keen to take it on with Club Rego. Also, from memory. Trade plates are only valid from 8am-5pm. Anything after that and you are asking for trouble. Especially if an accident occurs. Also, trade plates are a lot like Club Rego. You are not allowed/supposed to cut laps while on trade plates, even in the specified times. They are just so you can drive the car from one place to another.

posts.author: goober
posts.content: 1. Trade plate laws vary between states 2. SA and Vic are on par with trade plate laws 3. The trade plate is for the sole use of demonstrating a vehicle that is not registered or for trasnporting a vehicle from say dealership to mechanical garage. There are other minor exceptions to the rule but its simple. 4. If the trade plate is used outside of its designated use and an accident occurs the comp insurance as well as third party can be revoked. Also the bodily injury insurance can also be revoked. 5. A LHD car can only be regisitered if its 30 years old in Vic SA NSW QLD......not sure about WA or NT or ACT or Bathurst Island. 6. The only exceptions are: international guests with their cars, ie, US armed forces based in Pine Gap (when it existed) and Woomera SA. 7. 288GTO, F40, F50 cannot be registered until 30 years of age and compliance with ADR's is required. 8. 360 and 430 CH's cannot be registered because of the full roll cage, LHD and ADR failures. 9. A predecent was set with the McLaren F1 (cos no one knew how to rule a middle hand drive car) so i you want to roll the dice and play god with a trade plate.....then do it, have a prang and someone gets hurt......good luck! I have even tried legally with the F40 in WA and through a dealer there its basically a no go zone even though I was told of some 15 year rule and then again its ADR compliance that is the killer, those that have "cars" registered there are either doing it illegally or have found a now closed loop hole.

posts.author: Aircon
posts.content: OMG. you SO didn't get it!! How do you do that so often?

posts.author: goober
posts.content: Peter, I know this might be a tad hard to understand but the Govt here in SA appointed me to sit as an assessor in the Magistrates court to assist an appointed judge in deliberating on issues pertaining to the motor vehicle industry in SA. In 2006 I sat through a trial on the bench for 1.5 days over this exact issue. Some bloke decided to use a trade plate on a LHD corvette (86 cross flow), he was stopped by police on a Sunday and his defence stated that he was test driving the car. The judge did not see it that way and my opinion was that he was just out cruising. The judge came out with the act in regards to trade plates and tore it to pieces, he made me read it a gazzillion times and as such i took it in. After all evidence and stat decs were produced it came down to how the judge saw and interpreted the act. The decision was loss of drivers lic for 6 months, $650.00 fine and loss of trade plate for 2 years to the owner of the plate who was not the owner of the car but a mate who was a dealer. The final coup de ta was that the judge said and he pulled no punches in stating if an accident had occurred SGIC, the state bodily injury insurer would not cover the insurance because the accident whoever was at fault it didnt matter but that the vehicle was not registered and it was a failure to comply with the trade plate act. A provision is made in SA that if a car is unregistered the bodily injury insurance would still take hold because the insurance act states that a "balloon" needs to be set aside to cover someone who may have forgotten or couldnt be bothered to register a car. Trade plates are strictly enforced and if abused and an accident occurs......get ready to pay big time, the can of worms opened would lead to a very long stay in the court system and i believe far outweighing the benefit of driving a car that is unregisterable and non complied with ADR's. The moral is simple.....I wouldnt do it.

posts.content: oh well. Of course, we weren't talking about SA....I'm not even sure it's really a part of Aus!

snippet: i searched for this, and there seem to have been a few attempts to pull one together, but all of the referenced links have expired for some reason...
author: ross

posts.author: ross
posts.content: i searched for this, and there seem to have been a few attempts to pull one together, but all of the referenced links have expired for some reason and no longer function. is there one out there that is reliable and accessible?

posts.author: Manuel.G
posts.content: The only "accessible" I know (upon payment) is F-register, but it is not an exclusive registry for the F40.

posts.content: You can't be serious. Marcel Massini

posts.content: that "register" better than nothing ...

posts.author: Marcel Massini
posts.content: Good joke. Marcel Massini

posts.author: ross
posts.content: so is there one?

posts.author: joe sackey
posts.content: There are several, put together by various historians & model specialists who have observed the cars over the past 30 plus years and collated this information for the purposes of their business to the benefit of their clients. They often exchange information, and share updates. Marcel has one, as do I, as do others besides. Since the information in them is proprietary, these registries are not accessible by the public. That said, many of the holders of F40 registries generously share information on these forums to the benefit of the community.

posts.author: Manuel.G
posts.content: I take advantage of this topic created to say that I have a "registry" with ALL the F40s that have been registered in Spain. It is a "simple" record, enrollment date, enrollment, complete vin, combination ... I can have some extra information on some of them. I leave it said in case someone is interested in this information and wants to exchange information ... I was surprised to see an F40 with a US VIN register in Spain.

posts.author: ross
posts.content: thats great, but it doesnt really help the rest of us. i think there is a registry of enzo's put together by a guy here on fchat, and there are probably registries for the others - i have not looked. my question was whether there was one of these for the f40, and apart from your answer, it seems that nobody else has put one together for the use of the general public. shame.

posts.author: joe sackey
posts.content: Anyone can start and maintain one. There have been some public F40 registries before, but they either weren't comprehensive or they were abandoned when the register holder lost interest or enthusiasm, or simply didn't have the time to maintain them. I am not especially surprised by this because it takes many years of hard work & dedication to build a comprehensive register, cars are constantly being bought & sold, so an effective register requires constant updating. Checking quickly, there is one F40 register online right now with a few cars (11 of them!), perhaps there are others. There have been a number of previous requests about a register here on FChat as well also, however in this community when someone needs information about a specific car one of us is happy to oblige with helpful information.

title: F40 titles
snippet:
Just wondering how illegal or Legal this is?

Can we buy a title legally as in the Vin numbers of damaged / FIRE cars and get it rebuild....
author: 3604u

posts.author: 3604u
posts.content: Just wondering how illegal or Legal this is? Can we buy a title legally as in the Vin numbers of damaged / FIRE cars and get it rebuild. Been looking at this option but want to make it legal .

posts.author: PAUL500
posts.content: In the UK if the vehicle has not been struck from the DVLA registry via a cat A or B insurance marker then as long as you use the original chassis you can rebuild the car and have it registered here under its original number plate and VIN. Alternatively you can use a brand new chassis supplied by the manufacturer to transfer the VIN onto, however you cannot use an existing used chassis to do that to, otherwise you end up with a Q prefix on the numberplate and lose the official Ferrari name as the manufacturer on the title paperwork, which kills the value of the completed car anyway It all depends I guess which country the car is currently registered in, and where you actually want to register it. The only cars where it is financially viable to do such is when the cache of the model is worth more than the sum of its used parts. The classic example is the 250 SWB and GTO which can be built from scratch for under a million dollars, the VIN number then adds the rest of the value to the car. The other example was Rowan Atkinsons F1 which could be fully rebuilt for far less than its market value despite being virtually wiped out in the accident. I would say in order to do such with an F40 then the parts for the build could only come from dubious sources to get it built under its final completed value. Also in the days of internet information share, the truth will come out anyway, just look at the last two F40s at auction which have had ground up rebuilds, neither sold as a result.

title: 348 -> F40
snippet: ...of theorizing Stooge-style on stuff) about our favorite Ferrari, the F40.  It shares a lot of Ferrari DNA with our beloved 348's, so we were...
author: vvassallo

posts.author: vvassallo
posts.content: Plugzit and I were "Stoogestorming" (a kind of theorizing Stooge-style on stuff) about our favorite Ferrari, the F40.  It shares a lot of Ferrari DNA with our beloved 348's, so we were thinking about the next great Stooge project possibly being an F40 Homage based on a 348 donor car. What do you think?  How would you do it?  Here's our scope: Secure an early salvage title Berlinetta donor car, possibly a twin-disk clutch car.  Used race cars are possible. Remove everything that weights anything that doesn't make the car go fast.  Keep the A/C because F40's have it.  Go from front to back to create lightness.  The goal is a street legal, smog compliant, 2800 lb. car, less if possible, but we don't think that is likely.  We figured we'd need to lighten the front and rear bumpers, replace the exhaust system, dump the heavy interior parts, remove the trunk panels, change the headlight buckets to something fixed and glassed over like the Le Mans cars, replace the battery with a light lithium one, windows to manual opening, light weight seats, carpet swapped for another lighter material. Performance-wise we need to rebuild the engine with lower compression pistons for turbo charging, add turbos and intercoolers and aftermarket engine management.  Need higher flow injectors. Upgrade the front brakes at least, need performance 18" wheels and tires, add rear wing and front spoiler, either the SS lip spoiler or a modest tray. Optional stuff would be plexi windows, not the front windscreen, shock rebuild, sway bars, brake cooling ducts, remove side strakes, new paint and body work, etc. What would you guys do?  The all-in budget would be less than $100K.  Target output is around 500HP.  Can we get that out of 3.4 liters?  Remember the F40 has 2.9 liters displacement.

posts.author: kenneyd
posts.content: User paul500 is doing that with a 355 donor http://www.ferrarichat.com/forum/special-projects-concept-cars/430339-f40-bodied-f355.html

posts.author: itsablurr
posts.content: I would hope that it retains its 348-identifying features... strakes, pop-up lights, no wings or large aero. I think an F40-inspired build would be very cool... and likely end up in a way similar to the 348 GTCs, and CSAI-GT and Michelotto Competizione cars, where lightness, function, and race-derived elements are the points of inspiration. Liberal replacement of body panels with carbon fiber clones from front to back, stripped interior with carbon inner door panels, plexi windows, mousehair interior dash/console covering like in the F40 would be cool, F40/GTC or F40-US/SS seats, centerlock wheels, etc.

posts.author: ferrarisun
posts.content: Thanks for the update. A couple of questions, wonder if this F-40 was repaired, with values being quite a bit lower when apparently this crash happened, and, does Carfax cover cars in Canada, & do  their titles get branded salvage/rebuilt, as in the U.S. ?  With the amount of damage done, it should not have a clean title. Another great reason for getting a PPI.

posts.author: tr512
posts.content: In Canada If a car is branded a salvage/ rebuild it will show up on car fax.

posts.author: Gmaccormack
posts.content: Even if it's not a write off it will show up on car fax that it had a insurance claim for X amount and a little info in the reason why. Single vechile rear ended damage or similar. Only way to keep that off would be to pay for the damage out of pocket and you said he was fighting with Icbc so he's filed a insurance claim. It will be on the carfax. It's a f-40 the accident wil hurt its value but it doesn't look unfixable. SomeOne will still want it.

posts.author: tr512
posts.content: No ..for it to have a rebuilt/salvage title, it would of had to be a write off and will show on car fax.In B.C you can pay ICBC and check any cars history salvage or not just by the VIN.If i remember he wanted the car written off, but wanted to much money as a pay out.so ICBC said its going to fix the car.Just remember if you live in the U.S you can't bring a rebuilt/salvage car into the country.

posts.author: Gmaccormack
posts.content: Any accident with a claim filed will show up. Doesn't matter if it's a write off or not. The car fax will show it wasn't a write off and the claim was for X amount. A car that's been in a accident but not written off can be imported to the us. This f-40 as you say is worth to much for Icbc to write off and will be rebuilt if it hasn't already been. It will have the accident visible on the carfax.

This car would need to reach someplace like Ferrari of Houston, where the Wizard would take it behind the curtain and a new car comes out!! He paid for the images, he owns that property , why shouldn't he put measures in place to keep people from taking that for which he paid good money? Do you have an alarm on your house or your car? Do you hide your ATM pin from others? Why? What's the difference between you protecting your stuff and Christian protecting his stuff?

Perhaps you saw this (rather dubious) Ad? 1991 Ferrari F40 = Coming Soon = 16,000 km + 390,000 For Sale on Car And Classic UK [C296713] The Ad offers ZFFGJ34B000089692. The pics feature a car in Australia, and a car in the UK. Red flag number one. It suggests that the car is somewhat unavailable and located in Japan since the broker has an Oregon USA phone number (503 974 9215) and the F40 is "finishing mechanical restoration include new turbine and inspection of a fuel tank for YEN 9,000,000". Red flag number two. The broker asks: "Click this link for the pics" ANTEA cars / The Special Room For Clients Said pics are clearly a different car from the F40 in the Carclassic Ad above. Red flag number three. The Ad goes on: "Price: $$ Best Offer.... USD American dollars...". Best offer in today's F40 market? Red flag number four. A quick check on the phone number the broker uses reveals this from last year: http://www.ferrarichat.com/forum/141600686-post622.html And this: http://www.ferrarichat.com/forum/141600898-post623.html And this: http://www.ferrarichat.com/forum/141603278-post626.html Red flags numbers five, six & seven. There are other issues on other car forums (Musclecars & Maseratis!) with this same broker with the Oregon phone number, but I think at this point you can draw your own conclusions. I hope I am safe in suggesting that perhaps we have saved you, yet again!

title: f40 smoke
snippet:
had so much fun on my morning trip that i took her out again in the evening....

got stuck behind some grandmother from belgium in a honda going...
author: ross

posts.author: ross
posts.content: had so much fun on my morning trip that i took her out again in the evening.... got stuck behind some grandmother from belgium in a honda going about 2 miles an hour on a 2 lane for a couple miles. so i was loafing in a high gear doing about 1000 rpm. then the road widened and i took off.  all of a sudden white smoke starts pouring out the back, and the left hand 'stop engine' light came on.  so i pulled over and shut it down. got out, and raised the hood. the smoke was only emanating from the exhausts, and stopped after a few minutes.  the car was not exceptionally hot - water temp at 90 or less and oil temp about 1/3rd up the dial. since i was away from home, and could not see anything else, i got in and started and went on intending to just go home and park it.  but it ran fine - no issues, no smoke, no high temps, no funny noises, nothing. so i drove it around for another 30 minutes and it was fine. any ideas on the cause of the smoke? i am thinking that my left bank momentarily shut down during the low revs episode but fuel was still going in. so that when i revved to pass, the left bank came back on, and all the unburnt fuel lit at once and caused the smoke - and thats why it went away so quickly as well. anybody else?

posts.author: Bas
posts.content: Unburnt fuel would be black smoke. I'm thinking turbo seal (going) personally...

posts.author: JeremyJon
posts.content: could be Bas, hard to say by just that description though? typically, if the turbo oil seal is shot, it's either just after starting the car (being parked for a long time) or else it will keep on smoking non-stop

posts.author: PAUL500
posts.content: white smoke is typically oil getting into the turbo from the surrounding seals. They are actually tiny piston ring like not conventional seals, possibly one stuck and oil bypassed it for a time, normally though this happens under boost, and will get worse over time

posts.author: Noblesse Oblige
posts.content: I assume you downshifted before taking off.  You didn;t say at what RPM you observed the onset of white smoke.

posts.author: Bill S
posts.content: The stop engine light indicates exhaust temp is too high. Sounds like you were running rich on that bank when idling and then overheated the catalytic when taking off from the excess fuel in those cylinders. Not sure why this would occur. Could be a bad plug, ignition wire or even something with the injectors or fuel pressure regulator.

posts.author: texasmr2
posts.content: From my experience "white smoke" is a water issue and not an oil issue as oil smoke is black not white. Ross I would check ALL of your water lines/couplings as you could just have just worn out a seal or a loose fitting. I always used Teflon tape on these connections even after I upgraded to A/N fittings. Also you could have a cylinder head stud that has come loose which will allow water/coolant to be released. As Bas mentioned you could have a blown seal, these things happen within seconds and are no fault of your own. Please keep us informed ok? All the best, Gregg

posts.author: texasmr2
posts.content: Bill, The KISS method is often forgotten, thanks.

posts.author: PAUL500
posts.content: A water issue is steam so typically translucent not white smoke. Turbo oil is always white smoke due to high temp involved. Black smoke is a combustion related oil issue so rings/valve bypass etc Excess fuel is likewise black or brown smoke not white. It may well have been a combination of things under a chain of events rather than one isolated cause

posts.author: PAUL500
posts.content: The Weber Marelli system used on these cars, although old tech is still complicated to a degree, the wiring looms are very old now and start to have dry joints and loose connections. That would be my first port of call and relatively cheap to go through. An intermittent problem is usually wiring related

posts.author: texasmr2
posts.content: Good call.

posts.author: TimTifosa
posts.content: Sounds a bit similar to what happened in my car. See my post " slow down lights come on in Cat F40". In the end, disconnecting the cat overheat sensors seemed to have fixed the smoke.

posts.author: WILLIAM H
posts.content: Had same issue.  You need to swap the head gaskets.  Good luck finding some.  Took me near 2 years to find a pair.  I did hear of a shop out in west USA that makes them custom.  I'll see if I can find the shop again. The head gaskets are quite complicated and since there were only 2500 F40s built nobody makes them in such small quantities.  So we are Hosed

posts.author: PAUL500
posts.content: Re headgaskets, Tim is having his engine rebuilt (see LM resto thread) I am sure Cometic sell an uprated head gasket for the car.

posts.author: Traveller
posts.content: Correct and if you have an issue I can probably get you a set, just PM me

posts.author: ARTNNYC
posts.content: what is the update on this car?

posts.author: calder1
posts.content: We have been successful with Comtec gaskets

posts.author: ross
posts.content: i have not had time to take it out again to test any of these theories. sorry about that guys.

posts.author: ross
posts.content: took it out this morning for a spin. no smoke, or anything else. however, it still seems to have very short moments of hesitation and missing.  if i am at idle at a stoplight, there is a stutter every so often. this clears up when i press the accelerator to move.  later on, if i am at constant rpm i can feel it do that slight stutter again.  also, a couple times when i went from a cruising speed and rpm, to a lower gear and accelerated (ie to spool up the turbos), i got a moment of nothing.  the rpm's did not rise very fast and the whole thing seemed to be back on just the one bank, then i really pressed down on the accelerator and it all came to life and exploded forward. so, is this just the normal stuttering around of a high compression engine forced to moments of loafing in town, or is there still something wrong with the injectors, plugs, a short etc ??

posts.author: Maxige
posts.content: Doesn't seem right at all Ross...sounds like some kind of electrical issue to be honest.

posts.author: schao
posts.content: Sorry to hear of your troubles, Ross. Wouldn't an electrical issue be present at all points of the rev range? Maybe it's a fuel delivery issue, start inspecting and testing the simple things first. Pull the spark plugs and see if there is any color differences at the tip among all the plugs.

posts.author: PAUL500
posts.content: The weber marelli ecu will do a self diagnosis based on flash codes, these will indicate any sensor faults. The problem is they dont get stored so once you switch the engine off they will get deleted. It does sound like a dry of loose connector causes intermittent issues, hence the bank with that ecu playing up. Only real way is to leave it with a weber specialist so they can take the car out and download the code as it happens, otherwise you end up chasing your tail and replacing endless sensors.

title: F40 project.
snippet:
Hi, 

Since the moment I saw first time the F40 it become my "wet dream", when and where it was I don't remember. I'm not sure if I ever could...
author: sakne79

posts.author: sakne79
posts.content: Hi, Since the moment I saw first time the F40 it become my "wet dream", when and where it was I don't remember. I'm not sure if I ever could afford to buy one of them, I hope I could. This would after five, ten or maybe 20 years. There is one large issue, at that time it could cost around 2$-3$mil or more. Well, I don't want to wait so long. Same time I can't afford it now. I was start think about my current possibilities how to satisfy my dream and emotions. I think most of people who decide to buy F40, they are buying emotions, feelings etc not a car with four wheels and steering. Actually this is what I'm looking for too. In life it happened that I'm crazy about engineering and cars. As well I thought about investment object and you can call it four or fifth pension level. My idea is to built own F40 but with at least 70-80% OEM parts. I can start Today to work on this project and with every day small steps I will come closer and closer to my dream. I'm entrepreneur and there are always some business issue behind. Maybe it can turn in to something bigger. So, instead to save money in stocks, bonds and other stupid stuff, I decide to invest in F40. That I can afford with time. I'm owner of company what is in the industry of thermal cutting(plasma). I have possibility to do complicated assemblies in Solidworks, I have engineer who know how. My profession is production of non standard metalwork machinery. I'm not educated engineer, but I'm familiar with cnc, servo drive systems, welding etc. I'm looking for individual who would be so kind and help me with technical info of F40. Share or even sell. My first problem is, that it's impossible to buy F40 chassis(mine frame), even crashed. I will have to built it from scratch. Maybe somebody have one and could sell it to me for reasonable money. The rest of stuff, started from nuts till engine can be ordered at distributors or at Ferrari Classiche. I see my project done in 5-10 years. Estimate budget, as many as it will be neccesary. As a gift lot emotions, pain and dose of fun. Also self education process to better understand how to build the sports car.

posts.author: sakne79
posts.content: I couldn't find any information about manufacturing of Ferrari oval tubes. Do they produce by them self or it was outsourced in the 80'? Interesting to find out about some specific technical data. Why particular oval tube sizes was used in the production of F40 chassis? What the science behind it?

posts.author: BigTex
posts.content: They use GILCO for frames or did when my 308GTB was new. Good luck you'd be better off saving up and making wise financial investments. What you will find, is even real F40 owners have difficulty sourcing some parts. Welcome, in any case and your spirit is well placed.

posts.author: godabitibi
posts.content: I know Superformance UK sell the oval tube in specific lenght. Not cheap.

posts.author: sakne79
posts.content: Thanks for info. When I start to research the F40 chassis frame, pictures, forums, etc. I was wondering why it's built from so thin tubes and sheet metal. How does it hold the large stress created by engine torque and aerodynamic down force? It's seems like the F40 chassis is like two bicycle frames welded together side by side. It's probably so strong because the philosophy behind the chassis comes from bicycle, bike frame engineering. That's big step forward. I will speak with local bike folks and try to get more info about science stuff.

posts.author: sakne79
posts.content: Hi, Here it is: http://www.trafiltubi.com/index_eng.htm I wrote an email to them, will see what will be the answer.

posts.author: sakne79
posts.content: Interesting solution for everyone. A Programmer from New Zealand Is 3D Printing a Rare Aston Martin for $5,000 | Motherboard

posts.author: sakne79
posts.content: This is how far I'm with 2D CAD chassis. I have top and front, rear views as well. I'm not sure about some dimensions. But I'm very close. The popular picture of chassis blueprint on the web has lot of mistakes. After finishing the 2D CAD the 3D CAD will be created for manufacturing needs. Image Unavailable, Please Login

posts.author: bobzdar
posts.content: It's a space frame with CF and Kevlar shear panels.  This reduces weight as instead of triangulating with steel bars, you use the composite panels in shear to take the stress.  It looks like it wouldn't be very strong when you look at just the steel frame, and you're right it's not, you have to have the shear panels for the strength.  It's very strong and light when done correctly but not easy to make a car the magnitude of an F40 as your first project working with composites.  Luckily, composite manufacturing has come a really long way since the F40 was actually made so IMO it would be doable but lots of work and not inexpensive.

posts.author: sakne79
posts.content: Hi, I had a deal couple years agou with Arnis Irbens(from Latvia) from comany De-Tris. He made CF rear hood for my 200sx. If someone looking for real composite specialists, you can contact those guys. De-Tris Carbon Fiber Motocross Wheel Composite Whe

posts.author: Arnie
posts.content: Watch the 2 episodes of Fast and Loud on Discovery where they buy a wrecked F40 for $400,000 and rebuild it very interesting and fun.   Especially when they crack the $8000 windshield.  It is a step by step rebuild including frame straightening

posts.author: 246tasman
posts.content: I had an F40 project which I sold a couple of years back. I bought a burned out car from Japan about 4 years ago which had had the chassis number cut out from the frame as I think it should have been crushed after the insurance pay out, but someone had saved it. I mention this because at the same time we had a burned out 308 GTB chassis in the workshop. As soon as we had the F40 stripped down it was immediately obvious that the chassis were very very similar and clearly there wasn't much evolution from 308 to 288 to F40. I mention this because I think you could upgrade a 308 chassis quite easily. Work from how the F40 is done and get a decent race car chassis builder to advise you. I dont want to make you sick but I paid about £12k for the car which included a decent gearbox and rebuildable engine (though the heads needed replacing - Lancia LC30 heads are still available). I also got a brand new F40 engine for about £30k via Sheehan, and a stack of F40 LM parts, Enkei wheels, LM intercoolers, inlet trunking, LM turbos etc etc for about £12k in Switzerland about 3 years ago. Marcel Massini found the original chassis number from the engine and gearbox numbers on the burnt car. You can contact Simpson Motorsport UK who can supply almost everything to build an F40 at reasonable prices, including all the bodywork. Good luck!

posts.author: PAUL500
posts.content: I believe Simpsons were involved in the build of this one, using a 355 engine and box Could be the same car as mentioned I have also compared 308/328 and F40 dimensions, the evolution is obvious including not just the chassis but things such as doors, windscreen etc etc. A burned out/crashed 308/328 is a good donor Image Unavailable, Please Login Image Unavailable, Please Login

posts.author: bobzdar
posts.content: Somebody was looking at using a 355 as the greenhouse is almost the same and has the same wheelbase and wheel location as the F40 (which a 348 presumably would as well).  Then it'd just be a matter of removing all of the body panels, putting a radiator in the front and clothing with F40 panels.  The 348 even has a somewhat similar interior.  Of course, unless you cut out a ton of steel and replaced it with CF/Kevlar in the tub, it wouldn't be anywhere near as light as a real F40.

posts.author: sakne79
posts.content: My personal opinion about F40 and all that related replica stuff. I think, F40 represent the 20th century historical design heritage. In perfect world this should be respected. However it's not like that.  There are plenty cheap so called F40 replicas. F40 was technological innovation of late 80' and still is the symbol of super car. Why not use this unique design and  transform in to something even better. So, if the F40 is created as new it should represent today's modern technologies. From such point of view new car shouldn't be cheaper than 500K eur, and this is how it must be. Unfortunately I found just couple of F40 shaped projects with proper budget, attitude, and touch of 21th century.

title: F40 tachometer
snippet:
...ignition question here for anyone who is able to answer. 

Does the F40 have two ignition boxes? As in, one for each bank?  Or is it all...
author: Ferraripilot

posts.author: Ferraripilot
posts.content: Bit of a technical ignition question here for anyone who is able to answer. Does the F40 have two ignition boxes? As in, one for each bank?  Or is it all managed by one unit, if so, is the tach signal output on that box? I think this is the case, but is the F40 tachometer a square wave reading tachometer which accepts a V8 signal?  Or is it like 308/328 in that it's a 4 cylinder tachometer only accepting one banks signal because it manages the two banks seperately. thanks all

posts.author: EllisJuan
posts.content: I believe there is actually 4 ignition boxes/coils each running two cylinders.

posts.author: petrolfumes
posts.content: There are two ecu's and the tachometer signal is fed from the ecu for cylinders 5-8, or so say the wiring diagrammes. Whether they are all built that way is another question. Btw, there are indeed four coil packs.

posts.author: Ferraripilot
posts.content: many thanks!  so that means the tach is indeed a 4 cylinder unit.

posts.author: ross
posts.content: my left bank, 5-8 just shut down and the tach went with it, so this would seem to confirm the above. fwiw.

posts.author: JeremyJon
posts.content: so do aussie regulations not allow for the car being over a certain age, to be free of such restrictions? seems we're pretty lucky here then, in comparison

posts.author: F40LMGTC
posts.content: LHD cars (at least where I live in Victoria and there are different rules for different sates in Aus.), have to be 25 years old to be allowed "CLUB PLATE" rego. And for full rego (with a lot more rules and regulations), the LHD car has to be 30 years old. Normal "brand new" RHD cars can be registered with the normal rules and regulations just as a 50 year old normal RHD car can be registered as well.  But once you get into LHD cars, you're stuck with the 25 year old problem. In other words you couldn't bring in an ENZO and register it unless it is 25 yeas old. I'm gong to try to rgister my F40 next Jan 2012, because the first F40 were built in 1987 and 1987 - 2012  is 25 years. Club plates have some really amazing advantages, for example normal rego is around $650 (if you live in the city) $540 if you live 20 miles out of the city (approx). Club rego is around $70 or something like that.  We have another, lets call it a tax, which we call "transfer of registration fee, which is 8% of the price of the car.  e.g if you were to buy my F40 for say $700k and register it normally it would costs you 8% of $700k to have it transfered into your name.  With "club Plate rego", there is NO transfer of rego fee. Big saving right there. I have noticed recently since the new CLUB PLate rego rules came in which was the Jan-Feb this year, a lot of Ferrari guys are putting their cars on club plates. regards.....

posts.author: JeremyJon
posts.content: thanks Gil it's interesting to learn the differing rules around the world wow...at 8% that reg transfer (tax) is $56K   ouch!   sell it to your mother, and have her sell it back to you for $1  LOL i can certainly understand utilizing the club plate, doesn't make sense otherwise i'm really tempted to build a large private track after we move to NOLA, as it seems with increasingly greedy government agencies, and silly politics, that will be the only place to enjoy my sports cars!  like your F40-GTC is now i suppose

title: F40 Clutch?
snippet:
...cannot find a thread that I thought had some details on an upgrade from the factory F40 Clutch?

Anyone have a source?

Thanks very much,...
author: redcar1

posts.author: redcar1
posts.content: I've searched, but cannot find a thread that I thought had some details on an upgrade from the factory F40 Clutch? Anyone have a source? Thanks very much, Mark

posts.author: joe sackey
posts.content: Mark the guys at Risi will get it for you. Its an AP unit..

posts.author: TexasMike
posts.content: Mark, There is a guy down the street from my house who says he has lots of spare F40 clutches. He goes by mrknowitallf40 on here. You should send him a PM. http://www.ferrarichat.com/forum/member.php?u=16787

posts.author: mrknowitallf40
posts.content: The ap clutch is really pretty good.  Are you sure its not the bellhousing/hydraulic system? Many guys think it the clutch when its just a leaking bellhousing.  You can burn up the clutch pretty fast if the the system is leaking.  Nobody ever changes the clutch fluid and the reservoir is vented to atmosphere.  Griling makes a bellows that fits in the cap to stop this.  All of the f40's and 288's eventually need new bellhousings.  I switched to silicone fluid to avoid this.  I know it makes bad brake fluid but it works great in the clutch.  Stops the corrosion problem pretty quickly.  Look in your clutch reservoir to see if there is magnesium mud in it. What type of an upgrade do you want?

posts.author: Rifledriver
posts.content: AP makes a glycol based fluid that was specifically formulated for magnesium compatibility. I have been using it for years in 288+F40 with no outgassing of the mag which is what causes 95% of the hydraulic problems in those.  I have never had a bell housing sealed and have had zero problems. That fix was dreamed up by the factory because their fluid caused so much gassing in the mag.

posts.author: Drew Altemara
posts.content: Brian, I noticed Ferrari of Atlanta flushed and changed the clutch fluid on my F40 to silicone based DOT 5 brake fluid for the magnesium gassing issue last service. I assume the silicone fluid is better than DOT 4 brake fluid but that the AP glycol based material is the best solution? Regards, Drew Altemara

posts.author: mrknowitallf40
posts.content: Its the water in the fluid that causes the problem glycol or not.  The outgassing is hydrogen gas that is produced by the corrosion reaction between the bellhousing and the steel fittings that are screwed into it.  That bellhousing will corrode  and you cannot stop it ,only slow it down.  I am on my original bellhousing  and I have changed to stainless steel fittings which are less electrochemically active.  Silicone brake fluid does not absorb water and the new fluid is much better than it used to be.  What AP fluid are you refering to?  Most magnesium castings from the era were pretty porous and ceramic sealing the hydraulic conduit is not a bad idea.  A sleeve would even be better.  Being compatible with magnesium only means that it is PH adjusted to prevent corrosion on magnesium.  Once the fluid is  wet it  will still cause a problem.

posts.author: Rifledriver
posts.content: In my opinion it is.  Very few even know of the AP fluid because they don't promote it. I only found out about it because I wrote an article about brake fluid a number of years ago and discovered it doing research. Been using it ever since. F40 uses seperate reserviors so you can use 2 different fluids but 288 does not. I abhor the idea of silicon fluid in a brake system so this is a good choice.

posts.author: mrknowitallf40
posts.content: Silicone brake fluid is the only fluid that wont mix with water or absorb water.   It also has a neutral PH.  Its come a long way since the 70 when everyone in the SCCA used it because of its elevated boiling point.  Problem was that its compressible at high temperatures and used to give the feeling of a spongy pedal.  Better than no pedal.  Some have reported seal compatibility issues but that was a seal material problem.  Fact is that every brake system in the military from tanks to aircraft uses the stuff and it lasts forever and it completely noncorrosive.   All the motorcycle manufacturers use it as well.  Its come a long way since GE made it.  Repairing the clutch release bearing on an F40 is a big job.  Problem for us is that the factory does not retroactively fix issues.  I do have spare bellhousings but thats just so i dont have to refinish them!  In the clutch it really no issue.  What do you feel is the downside?

posts.author: mrknowitallf40
posts.content: Does this mean that we will never know the identity of the afore mentioned fluid?  What did you use before you did research for your article?

posts.author: mrknowitallf40
posts.content: Ap racing does not make a fluid specifically for clutches.  They make only brake fluid.  Any of their products can be used in the clutch system.  AP 551 is recommended.  AP 600 is specifically warned not to be used in conjunction with magnesium due to its corrosive nature and nonneutral ph.  Mystery solved.  Just dont use AP 600 in the clutch. Fine for the brakes.  Thanks Brian you almost got it right.  All the AP fluids are glycol based as are most others.  The big exception being Castrol SRF.

posts.author: nine11tec
posts.content: Hi, can you private message me?  I would like to learn more about having a bellhousing repaired, as I feel I have one that is starting to exhibit signs of the dreaded internal corrosion.  Thank You! Jordan

title: F40 mileage
snippet:
What do you consider to be low, average or high mileage on an F40, considering the model is an average of 20 years old?

For example:

Low...
author: joe sackey

posts.author: joe sackey
posts.content: What do you consider to be low, average or high mileage on an F40, considering the model is an average of 20 years old? For example: Low mileage = delivery mileage to 10,000. Average mileage = 10,000 to 30,000. High mileage = beyond that point. I bet owners and enthusiasts alike have a different perspective on this, and my thoughts are that the numbers will be lower for those in the USA as compared to those outside the USA. Please share your thoughts and thank you in advance for participating..

posts.author: ttforcefed
posts.content: my 2 cents: low < 5K miles average 5 to 10K high >10k

posts.author: Simon^2
posts.content: Hi Joe. I break it out a bit different: Ultra low:  Under 1500 Very Low: 2-4K Low: 4-7K Avg:  7k-9,999 Mod:  10-15K High:  >15K

posts.author: Napolis
posts.content: Generally I've found that to add one million dollars to a car's value it's necessary to drive it about 3000 miles in a 24 hour period in a recognised speed contest.

posts.author: kverges
posts.content: I am with Joe more than the others.  F40s are now getting to be 20 years old or more. How much use do you think is important to get fluids fully warmed?  I'd say you should drive at least 30 miles once a month, which over 20 years is 7200 miles - still under 10K and "low" in my view.  A car with under 5,000 miles is driven under an average of 20 miles a month - probably not properly warmed up each drive and I'd personally shy away from it (unless I want a static museum piece not really intended to be driven).  Just passed 14K on ours which is an average of 60 miles a month over its life, not exactly huge mileage.  The use we give it means filters, selas, gaskets, belts, fluids, etc are current, changed and used enough to do their jobs.

posts.author: joe sackey
posts.content: Jim: that is a great recommendation, but, I would be afraid that something might break!

posts.author: joe sackey
posts.content: A great way of looking at this debate. Which begs the question with the "low" mileage cars, at what mileage point does driving the car no longer take away from premium value?

posts.author: cirugiadigestiva
posts.content: I,m a f40 owner with 30.000 km, my car is perfect, in my opinion a 20 years old car with 3000 km is not a car is and investissement, and in my opinion this car can have more problems ad a car with 35000km with a perfect services with a full dossier and used regulary. I had some ferrari,s, one of the more probematic had a 412 with 1000 km in 15 years, oil leaks, climatitation unwork, electric problems, original exhaust dead, etc, etc for my the best ferrari is a regulary used car, with a perfect dossier and probably from another ferrari collector.

posts.author: Drew Altemara
posts.content: When I purchased an F40 earlier in the year I felt there were 3 classes of cars avaialble to purchase. 1)  Under 5,000 mile show cars that commanded a significent premium. 2) Unmodified cars in the 5-8,000 to 12-15,000 mile range that commanded a premium. 3) Modified cars that sold at significent discount even though every owner said the mods were bolt on; they were not. I ended up buying a 14,000 mile unmodified car because I was going to drive it around 1,000 miles per year and I wanted a car that had not been messed with.  The only rub against the car I bought through Joe S was that it was higher mileage and priced accordingly. I tend to agree with Joe's initial accessment of mileage but IMO I feel the modified vs. unmodified issue is an order of matter of greater importance in a numer of buyer's minds; at least it was in mine. Enjoy hearing your responses. Drew Altemara

posts.author: StoryBook
posts.content: I'd have to agree with Ricky's assessment I'd reckon right around the 5780 mile mark

posts.author: Napolis
posts.content: I'm with you.  I've put well over 600K miles on my cars.  Every weekend I drive at least two of them at least 100 miles through twisty roads.  P 4/5 now has about 8K miles.

posts.author: thirteendog
posts.content: Lol @ the OP, I misread your title and thought this thread was about mileage as in MPG.  Was going to say, who the hell cares.

posts.author: stradman
posts.content: You know it really does depend. I have just bought 1988  road version of a  group B car that has a confirmed 4500 miles on it. But the car looks as though it has done 15000 miles on it! Ok as a result I bought it a significant discount, and I bought it with the aim of effectively recommissioning it entirely, including an engine rebuild! The car basically did most of its miles in the first 9 years of its life then sat around the remainder collecting dust. So what that it has a very low mileage. I have seen cars with three times that mileage in pristine condition. So its not really that much about mileage but the condition. Overall I prefer it if a 20 year old car has between 8-12k miles on it because, like others have already stated, it means the moving parts have actually had a chance to do just that.... And its also less likely to have been forgotten by the owner because it was stuck in storage. Out of sight means out of mind!

posts.author: joe sackey
posts.content: Understood, what your preference is. But, per the OP, "What do you consider to be low, average or high mileage on an F40" ??

posts.author: joe sackey
posts.content: Thanks for your input Drew. Interesting comments about the mod cars that are claimed to be reversible but are not-so-much. Bob Houghton mentions the same thing in the November 2010 issue of Octane's Ferrari F40 Buying Guide.

The major thing with an F40 in particular is with a higher mileage it usually means several owners, one of whom will treat the car roughly. That is anything from hitting a curb to not bothering with proper services.

posts.content: An F40 was sold in Australia recently with only 200 kilometers on the speedo. A 20 year old car with 125 miles on the clock

posts.author: Rifledriver
posts.content: IMO that is a backwards perspective. Buying a low or very low mileage car of this type should be done for two reasons only. Reason one is for its long term collector value in which case it should be driven as little as possible, like from the trailer to the show grounds and the reviewing stand. Many of  the collectors I know fall into this catagory and many own another same or similar car to drive. Reason two, your own personal time machine. You really wanted one new but were a starving student and couldn't afford it. Now you can and every bit of patina can be yours. Not a bad choice either because in folding money an extreme low mile F40 is still cheaper the the selling premium they were going for in 1990 and if you calculate adjusted dollars even at todays price you are stealing it. We got a 10 year old TR with 900 miles for reason two. We paid less than 1/3 what the original owner did and with any luck I will live long enough to wear it out. It was cheap looked at with the correct perspective and every rock chip and leather crease is ours.

posts.author: joe sackey
posts.content: Good point, and I think that as F40s transcend 20 years of age, mileage becomes less of a factor relative to condition and maintenance history, in determining value.

posts.author: Tenney
posts.content: Seems about right - though might add the in-the-wrapper/delivery miles cars at under 1K miles, as a good few were moth-balled from the get-go as future time capsule collectibles.  Would guess these will always represent the high-end of the market, other than perhaps the prototypes - which may be mileage-proof due to their rarity.

posts.author: F40 LeMans
posts.content: yeah the prototype... http://blog.hemmings.com/index.php/2007/05/03/days-of-ferrari-day-xvi/ 74049’s true singularity lies in its powerplant. The standard F40 engine is a Tipo F120A, while the higher output F40 LM used a Tipo F120B. Interestingly, the engine plate on 74049 states that it has a Tipo F120AB, which may be a cross between the two. Although most major components are the same as a standard F40, 74049 is believed to produce about 100hp more than the 478hp that a European model F40 produced (tested at 7,500 rpm without air passing through the intercoolers). This makes it only about 160 horsepower shy of an LM. The IHI turbos are different from stock, but not the same as the ones on an LM. The ECU is an enhanced one-off unit. Intercoolers are standard, but do not wear the BEHR lettering of the street units. As with European models, there is no catalytic converter and many of the brackets for the exhaust system are hand-fabricated. The air cleaners are also subtly different for no apparent reason. The fuel cell housing is made from carbon fiber. BTW factory experience cars were a various type of experimental cars, but there are some stock cars with in the experience cars.

posts.author: rossocorsa13
posts.content: You're a trooper and a gentleman, Pap. If you were in TN, I'd let you drive me around in the snow!

posts.author: Bill S
posts.content: It becomes more fun as you learn about it. We just got back from a night drive. If you keep the revs up the power is good and the turbo lag is much shorter. Brakes are OK once you get used to them, and so is the shifter and the steering. It's noticeably faster than the GT3 RS in a straight line. In the curves, the RS is easier to drive faster because there is less body flex for better road feel and the steering, brakes and acceleration are instant with no waiting. But unless you're on a track, the F40 will stay with the RS OK. One big difference - the RS brakes will make your eyes pop out. You're not going to get that with the F40. Other than that, the RS (and CS) feel pretty much as raw as the F40 since there's not much electronics saving your butt in those cars. The sounds the F40 makes coming in and out of boost are pretty entertaining. I think that's one of the things I enjoy most about the F40. It's amazing how much the sound of a car adds to the driving pleasure, at least for me.

posts.author: Bill S
posts.content: We stopped after a long straight and a boy and his little brother came running down the hill. The brother, probably about 10 or 11, said he heard me coming down the straight (7,000+ rpm!) and knew it was a Ferrari. I guess he runs down the hill all the time to see the cars go by when he hears them coming. He almost had a heart attack that an F40 and RS actually stopped in front of his house! That never happened before! That's why his older brother joined him this time. We talked for a bit and gave them a good show when we left. Too bad I didn't think to offer them a ride. Maybe next time I see them.

posts.author: E40racer
posts.content: Tipo is Italian for type.

posts.content: 1989. First US version built had VIN ZFFMN34A1L0084729. Marcel Massini

posts.content: I assume this is a 1990 model year, possibly delivered in 1989?  i.e., not a model year 1989 Thx - Tim

posts.author: frefan
posts.content: Never seen a US 89

posts.author: joe sackey
posts.content: Marcel is correct that the car was built in 1989, but for purposes of the USA DOT, it is strictly a 1990 model year car. Therefore to answer the OP's question correctly, the first model year for the USA is 1990. USA cars have model years 1990, 1991 and 1992 ascribed to them.

posts.author: Napolis
posts.content: "1. What was the first year the F40 was imported as a USA model?" The first year the F40 was imported as a USA Model was 1989 as Marcel correctly pointed out. As Mike pointed out the "model year" was 90 but it was imported in 1989.

posts.author: joe sackey
posts.content: I'm not sure any USA F40s reached here till early 1990. But I could be wrong...

posts.author: Marcel Massini
posts.content: Sorry, it was ME who was wrong. I double checked my database again. I saw 84729, the first US version F40 built, at the factory in Maranello, undergoing construction on March 24, 1990, (NOT 1989). Of course, 84729 is Model Year 1990, not 1989. My apologies for the incorrect information. The second US F40 built was 84838 and it was built May 1990. It went new to Steven Kessler Motorcars in NY who then sold it to first owner E. B. in Naples/FL. Marcel Massini

title: F40 Rotors
snippet: Any suggestions for replacement rotors for the standard factory issue, grooved preferably, not cross-drilled.  Also what pad would suit said...
author: Gleggy

posts.author: Gleggy
posts.content: Any suggestions for replacement rotors for the standard factory issue, grooved preferably, not cross-drilled.  Also what pad would suit said rotors. Mg

posts.author: rexrcr
posts.content: We did this a lot in the 90's as OE was so pricey. Used both Brembo and Alcon rotors. Turns out the OE Brembo is a size shared by Cup cars and others (Trans Am, etc.). For max performance I recommend the Alcon as thier metalurgy is a little different and they lasted longer under track conditions but were more expensive. Brembo changed thier mount ears design and we had to machine the lip from the rotor hat, not a big deal; Brembo may have changed this again, I haven't done this mod for a long time. Use slotted only for maximum life and performance under track conditions, choose drilled for the OE look. Pads, lots of good options; I'm biased toward Pagid, the OE supplier. Pagid blue was the original factory spec pad. Call a Brembo or Alcon dealer they've had this application for 20 years. You can also go with one of FChat's many performance parts suppliers. Best, Rob

posts.author: mrknowitallf40
posts.content: I have a new set of brembo replacement rotors that are slotted and drilled.  From what I understand they are not offered this way anymore.  contact me if you are interested.

posts.author: coachi
posts.content: I know everyone knows that the european seats with the two holes on the top part that accomodate their seatbelts are not original equipment on US cars.  I have seen one example that was converted to those seats because I suppose they can accomodate Stabilt seat belts for the track. Also, I have had one seat recovered locally...we bought the red material and had it recovered.  There is no need to buy new seats unless there is something wrong with the original seats. Just my .02 worth

posts.author: Tipo815
posts.content: Why are all of you searching for seats?  What happened to your old seats where you need a replacement?  Why not recover/refresh them like coachi did? I bought my car with 5400 miles on it and the seats were in perfect condition.  I have since removed and replaced them with OMP carbon fiber racing seats which are better supporting, lighter, and I don't mind wearing them out. My factory seats are covered and in storage for the next owner!

posts.author: Tipo815
posts.content: Might I suggest to some of you - in order to preserve your factory seats - consider installing some nice aftermarket carbon seats.  I don't have a close up photo of my carbon seats but this pic shows you a partial view.  They are my lighter than the factory seats and have excellent support.  They also work perfectly with the over the shoulder four point harness.  I bought the seats with regular red material and had them recovered in red alcantara. Image Unavailable, Please Login

posts.author: StoryBook
posts.content: Jeffrey, do you have the model number of those OMP seats?  And did OMP recover in alcantara for you? TIA

posts.author: joe sackey
posts.content: + 1 Joe www.joesackey.com

posts.author: Tipo815
posts.content: The seats were out of a 360 Challenge race car.  I don't believe OMP actually makes this same seat in carbon fiber for the retail market.  It is the GRIP model but OMP only makes this model with a fiberglass shell.  I believe that all the carbon shell seats were made exclusively for Ferrari (yet another Ferrari monopoly on something ).  The carbon shells of my seats have a very similar weave/color to the actual carbon/kevlar that appear under the hood and engine hatch - sort of the light tan color.  It matches perfectly. One of my closest friend's cousin does all the custom interior for the DUB show cars.  I gave him a photo of the design of seat (quilted look) and he matched it perfectly in alcantara.  If you find a set of seats that need recovering I can help you.  He's also a fraction of the cost of anyone else (probably because of my relationship with my buddy).  Anyway, if you (or anyone) needs help with recovering seats - I know the person!

posts.content: My seats are not only fading, the drivers side seat has a few visible stress lines from entering and exiting the car. title: F40 clutch
snippet: Yesterday I noticed that my F40 clutch felt different than other F car clutches I had driven before.  It seemed that the clutch engaged with very...
author: coachi

posts.author: coachi
posts.content: Yesterday I noticed that my F40 clutch felt different than other F car clutches I had driven before.  It seemed that the clutch engaged with very little pedal release...no slipping or gear crunching...felt "odd" to me...can anyone enlighten me on how their F40 clutches feel?  Thanks

posts.author: redcar1
posts.content: It definitely has a different feel than other Ferrari clutches.  Mine always feels very stiff and awkward until I get re-accustomed to it. Mark

posts.author: WCH
posts.content: I was forced to take my car out so I could answer your question.  Seemed like a small sacrifice to make for a fellow fchatter. Clutch pedal action of course is quite firm.  My clutch releases very low, and very quickly.  All business.  I agree with redcar that, if you've been driving other manuals, you may need to readjust to the F40 clutch.

posts.author: coachi
posts.content: My impressions as best as I can describe them:  the clutch depresses easily, nothing hard about it and when I release it, it engages very quickly...could that be a bad clutch?

posts.author: WCH
posts.content: "the clutch depresses easily, nothing hard about it and when I release it, it engages very quickly...could that be a bad clutch?" You need someone with far more tech knowledge - but my F40 clutch pedal effort is high, you need to get some leg into it to depress it - though, like yours, it engages very quickly, with the pedal still quite close to the floor. Wish I could really help you. Good luck, Will

posts.author: coachi
posts.content: thanks for the help..i appreciate that

posts.author: Simon^2
posts.content: My clutch is firm but not excessive.  Not as hard as a 512TR, for example.  The "bite" range of the travel is fairly short, but occurs about 1/3 back from full depression.

posts.author: ROLOcr
posts.content: maybe it needs to be bled? when was the last time you changed the clutch fluid

posts.author: Rifledriver
posts.content: Have you had it long? I only ask because your description sound like an F40 clutch to me. Just need to become familiar.   Drive it, thats not too much to ask.

posts.author: ferrarifixer
posts.content: If it bites low to the floor on the way up, and the top end feels a little stodgy if you just touch it lightly, it probably needs to be bled/change fluid. The effort increases as they get worn, but they're still lighter than some models... BB/TRossa for example.

posts.author: Harmonyautosport
posts.content: Bleed out the fluid, should fix it.

posts.author: coachi
posts.content: thanks

posts.author: ferrarifixer
posts.content: of course... an annual service would see to this.... is the car up to date with servicing... if your clutch is aeriated, chances are you have some other deferred maintenance... prevention is better than cure...

posts.author: davehelms
posts.content: If air in the clutch hyds is the problem, There is a problem with the F40 magnesium bellhousing creating air in the clutch hydraulics.  The magnesium has an "Out Gasing" problem that is fixed by having it treated with a Mil-Spec coating designed for sealing magnesium. Bleed the clutch hyd's first and see if the problem reoccures before jumping to that conclution.  In the last few years I have found numerous 40's with that problem just now starting to show up. Dave

posts.author: zsnnf
posts.content: The other wing on my car was one of the first Tubi wings. They are no longer available. That wing was clear coated for show. The consistency of the wing profile was pretty bad. This wing is a lot stronger and the quality is much better. Without a rear wing, my car is able to spin the rear tires at 100 mph on the freeway. With this wing it will not spin them at 70mph. I don't have lap times to compare, but the rear of the car does stick much better in the corners. This wing was on Amirs F40 when he set the record at the Virginia City Hill climb. So I know it works. Actually, I never said it was a "Copy". I said it has the same wing shapes. As I stated above, the Tubi wing we had as a sample was really pretty bad. This first wing did not have the end plates drilled for adjustment. A new set  that is adjustable is now fitted. There is also a Gurney flap available for maximum down force.

posts.author: f40carlo
posts.content: Hi All; I have a US 1991 model F40.  The exhaust is the Tubi that starts after the cats  (I call it very quiet).   Can I just get a cat 'bypass pipe' , store the cats elesewhere, and be good to go?? Questions:   Will it be ridiculously lleaving the current Tubi set-up intact, but circumventing the cats? IS this a viable set-up?  or... Do I have to take a different approach? Second I am looking at the chip from www.tap1.com which comes with new valves for the turbos to increase boost pressures.   $595.  Anybody know anything about it?   It's in the FCA monthly...claims max 565hp with the setup.   Seems cheap! Thanks to all for your help! Carlo

posts.author: carguy
posts.content: First off....I'm in awe of your car, the F-40 is an icon.  I have heard an F-40 with just a Tubi, no cats, and it was "growly" but not too loud.  This is a subjective opinion and I'm one who likes to hear the car a bit.  The turbos do muffle the exhaust note somewhat also.  If it were me I'd remove the cats and put them in storage for the future.  I'm sure some more experienced F-40 people will speak up.....

posts.author: Steve
posts.content: I'm using a TAP chip in both my 512TR and 348 Spider, and both have worked fine. Although, I have a strange "flat spot" at the top of the HP and Torque curve on the dyno on my 512, and still have to investigate to see if it's the chip that's causing it. I am using a Carobu Engineering chip in my F40. I couldn't find anything about the valves on the TAP site. How exactly are they messing with the boost? Be VERY careful there... Also, the page talking about the chip on the TAP site asks for the bosch part number for the ECU. That would make me a little worried - the F40 ECUs are Weber-Marelli. SteveJ

posts.author: 410SA
posts.content: It will still weigh a lot less than any 308 so it will probably be a tad faster!

posts.author: Steve
posts.content: Yes it was a self install. I don't remember the exact price for just the chip (they sell it as part of the LM turbo kit), but I think it was a little bit north of $1K. I recommend getting a friend who has experience installing these types of chips, because they can be a little tricky sometimes. Radio Shack makes an IC installer that really works well. The Carobu chips are designed to be used with the LM turbos only, which if you haven't already done it is the best upgrade you can do for your F40. I believe I'm averaging around 19lbs of boost. But that's not solely determined by the chip. You can modify the wastegate spring tension to adjust that (be careful and search the forum for a few threads that address this before doing so).

title: F40 Turbos
snippet: So I blew a seal on the left bank turbo this weekend just running down the street for some milk.  Scared the cr&p out of me as the backend of the...
author: red-riot

posts.author: red-riot
posts.content: So I blew a seal on the left bank turbo this weekend just running down the street for some milk.  Scared the cr&p out of me as the backend of the car was covered with a nasty mixture of oil and coolant?  Once we tore it down it was apparent the problem came from the turbo. I was hoping to get some opinions on upgrading to the LM Turbo setup that Carabou racing is marketing.  I've gotten several comments from the folks who rebuild the engine that the LM turbo's are too big for the type of street driving I do and would probably be disappointing unless I planned to track the car.  Their comments are that the larger turbos take longer to spool up, so I'd experience more lag at the bottom end.  I spend most of my miles on the street as I only get to the track once or twice a year so I'm not looking to build a top-end monster. I also got a strange response from FNA when I asked about availibility of a replacement turbo, they said that there where two turbos mfged, a standard on the older cars and an "enhanced"  they said they only have enhanced in stock so if I indeed have the older turbos I'd have to replace both?  Anybody ever hear of this? Any advice would be greatly appreciated! Thanks Jon

posts.author: ivo73
posts.content: hello Jon, the only information that i can give you is that,that the turbochargers supplier ( IHI) produced new turbo's in 1995. new part number 164358 and 164359 in replacement of the older part no.152161 and 152162. I'm not sure if the part number changed again in the last years.... hope this helps a little. regards from switzerland ivo

posts.author: zsnnf
posts.content: Hi Jon, Here's what I am lead to believe..... Yes, the only turbo that is available now IS the updated turbo. I believe this is the turbo that was refered to as the "LM" turbo. It is not bigger. It has roller bearings instead of bushings. The inlet does provide better airflow. The impeller design is improved also. It actually comes in sooner, not later. Therefor it is more driveable, not less. So your choices are to either rebuild your turbo, find a used one (I have 2 but I don't want to sell yet) (they make great upgrades for a 288) Or buy the new turbos with new chips. You should see another 35+/- HP with this change. You can get the Turbos and chips from Rod at FAI 949 631-6373 or from Tate at Carabu 949 722-9307. Rod should be a little cheaper. I think he builds the chips for Tate. Rick

posts.author: mrknowitallf40
posts.content: A few years back I bought just the turbos from Rutland's for $3800/pair
